title: Constantine I of Imereti
text:
Constantine I (, "Konstantine I"; died 1327), from the House of <a href="Bagrationi">Bagrationi</a>, was king of the western <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a>n <a href="kingdom%20of%20Imereti">kingdom of Imereti</a> from 1293 to 1327.
Accession and civil war.
A son of the Georgian king <a href="David%20VI%20Narin">David VI Narin</a> and his wife, <a href="Amanelisdze">Tamar Amanelisdze</a>, or a <a href="Palaiologos">Palaeologian</a> princess. Constantine succeeded to the throne of Imereti upon his father's death in 1293. Unlike his eastern Georgian counterparts, Constantine remained independent from the <a href="Ilkhan%20Empire">Ilkhanid</a> hegemony, but he faced serious internal unrest as his younger brother <a href="Michael%20I%20of%20Imereti">Michael</a> opposed his accession and seized control of the regions of <a href="Racha">Racha</a>, <a href="Lechkhumi">Lechkhumi</a>, and <a href="Argveti">Argveti</a>. In vain did the nobles of Imereti try to reconcile the brothers and internecine conflict continued to upset the country. 
The great nobles took advantage of the situation to assert their autonomy. <a href="Giorgi%20I%20Dadiani">Giorgi I Dadiani</a>, <a href="Principality%20of%20Mingrelia">Duke of Mingrelia</a>, subjugated much of the <a href="duchy%20of%20Tskhumi">duchy of Tskhumi</a> and expanded his possessions up to <a href="Anacopia">Anacopia</a>. The <a href="House%20of%20Shervashidze">Shervashidze</a> entrenched in Abkhazia, the <a href="Gurieli">Gurieli</a> in <a href="Principality%20of%20Guria">Guria</a>, and <a href="Vardanisdze">Vardanidze</a> in <a href="Principality%20of%20Svaneti">Svaneti</a>, showing little subservience to the royal authority. Constantine died amid these disturbances in 1327, having had no children, and his brother Michael succeeded him as king.
Culture.
Constantine is known to have restored <a href="Monastery%20of%20the%20Cross">Monastery of the Cross</a> in <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> to the Georgian ownership in 1305. He also had the monastery refurbished and repainted. His contributions are emphasized in a document instituting the <a href="Agape%20feast">Agape feast</a>, in his own lifetime, on 21 May, the <a href="feast%20day">feast day</a> of <a href="Constantine%20the%20Great">Constantine the Great</a>. Constantine might have been an unidentified royal person depicted on a fresco in <a href="Ienashi%20church">Ienashi</a> in <a href="Upper%20Svaneti">Upper Svaneti</a>. His links to that region is also known from a charter issued by Constantine to the <a href="Svans">Svan</a> Goshkoteliani clan.
